10:15
engine crawling. Search engines like Google use automated programs called crawlers or spiders to browse the web.
10:22
So these crawlers follow links from one web page to another collecting information about each page they visit.
10:29
They gather data on the content structure and other elements of the web pages which is then stored in the search
10:35
engines database. Now next one is search engine indexing. Once the crawlers
10:40
collect information about web pages, the data is organized and stored in a massive database called an index. The
10:47
indexing process involves analyzing the content keywords, meta tags, and other factors to understand what each web page
10:54
is about. This index information allows search engines to quickly retrieve relevant results when someone performs a
11:00
search query. All right. Now, the third one which is search engine ranking. When a user enters a search query, the search
11:07
engines algorithms shift through the index pages to determine which ones are most relevant to the query. The
SEO for Beginners

24:56
today's video is just for you. We are diving deep into keyword research, a crucial part of any successful SEO
25:02
strategy. By the end of this tutorial, you'll know exactly how to find the right keywords to help your content
25:08
reach its full potential. So, let's get started. To kick off things first, let's
25:14
understand what keyword research is. Now, keyword research is all about discovering the exact phrases and terms
25:21
your potential audience is typing into search engines. Now, by identifying these keywords, you can create content
25:27
that directly addresses what people want to know, buy, or learn about. This not
25:33
only drives more visitors to your site, but also helps you connect with those who are most likely to engage with your
25:39
content. In essence, keyword research is the backbone of a strong SEO strategy,
25:45
guiding you in crafting content that resonates with your audience. Now that we know what keyword research is, let's
25:52
dive into why it's so important. Picture this. You're hosting a party. Would you
25:57
invite random people who might not even be interested? Or would you carefully choose guests who are excited to attend?
26:04
So, keyword research helps you do the latter by attracting the right guests to your website. When you know the exact
26:11
keywords your audience is searching for, you can tailor your content to meet their needs. This increases your chances
26:17
of not only driving more traffic, but also engaging visitors who are genuinely interested in what you have to offer.
26:23
The better you understand your audience search behavior, the more effective your content will be. Remember, it's not just
26:30
about quantity. Getting the right kind of traffic is key to conversions and overall success. Moving on, let's talk
26:37
about the different types of keywords you'll encounter in your research. This is important because not all keywords
26:43
are created equal and understanding the distinctions can greatly impact your strategy. So, short tail keywords are
26:50
broad and usually consist of one or two words like SEO or marketing. Now, these
26:56
keywords have high search volumes which means lots of people are searching for them. However, they're also highly
27:03
competitive, making it tough to rank for them unless you have a very authorative website. Next comes longtail keywords.
27:10
Now, longtail keywords on the other hand are more specific phrases like how to do
27:16
keyword research for SEO. Now, while they have lower search volumes, they tend to be less competitive and more
27:22
targeted, attracting visitors who are further along in their buyers journey. For instance, someone searches for best
27:29
budget laptops for students is likely closer to make a purchase than someone just searching for laptops. Now, next
27:36
type of keyword is LSI, which is Latin semantic indexing keywords. Now, these
27:41
are related terms that search engines consider relevant to your main keyword. Now, for example, if your main keyword
27:47
is digital marketing, then LSI keywords could be online marketing, SEO strategies or social media advertising.
27:54
Now even in this example if you have given best leather shoes the LSIs would be official and casual wear best
28:00
footwear brand urgent leather shoes etc. So using LSI keywords helps you create more contextually relevant content with
28:08
search engines favor. Now by balancing these types of keywords you can create content that appeals to both broad and
28:14
niche audiences giving your website a better chance to rank well across different searches. So all right, now
28:20
that we have covered the types of keywords, let's explore some of the tools that can help you find them. So
28:26
keyword research tools are like treasure maps. They guide you to the keywords that can drive the most traffic to your
28:31
website. Number one is Google keyword planner. So Google keyword planner is a fantastic starting point, especially for
28:38
beginners. It's free and provides a wealth of information, including search volumes and competition levels for
28:44
various keywords. You can also discover new keyword ideas based on what people are already searching for. Next is
28:51
ahrefs. Ahres is a more advanced paid tool that offers in-depth analysis. It
28:57
doesn't just give you keyword data. It also provides insights into how difficult it is to rank for a particular
29:02
keyword as well as clickthrough rates, CTR, and related keyword ideas. So, ASF
29:08
is particularly useful for competitor analysis, helping you see which keywords for your competitors are ranking for and
29:14
identifying gaps in their content that you can exploit. Now, next comes SEM Rush. Now, SEM Rush is another powerful
29:21
tool that goes beyond keyword research. It offers comprehensive data on keywords, including trends over time,
29:28
and allows you to conduct competitive analysis, track keyword performance, and more. SEM Rush is a go-to for many SEO
29:36
professionals because of its all-in-one capabilities. So, these tools simplify the process of keyword research,
29:42
allowing you to focus on creating content that will resonate with your audience and perform well in search engine results. So, with so many tools
29:49
at your disposal, the next step is figuring out how to actually find the best keywords for your content. So,
29:55
here's a step-by-step approach. Number one, start with a brainstorming session.
30:01
So you can list down potential keywords related to your topic. Think about what your audience might search for and
30:07
consider different variations of those phrases. So use the keyword research tools we just discussed to analyze these
30:14
keywords. Pay close attention to search volume, competition, and user intent.
30:19
The goal is to find keywords that have a good search volume but aren't too competitive. And next, consider user
30:25
intent. This is crucial. Ask yourself, what is a searcher hoping to find? If someone is searching for best travel
30:31
laptops in 2024, they're probably looking for product reviews or recommendations. Tailor your content to
30:38

1:21:43

1:21:49

1:21:55

1:22:36

1:22:49

1:22:55

1:23:02
off-site engagement. So SEO being a major channel for most companies and
1:23:07
websites where the opportunity to drive a lot of traffic is there but you have to earn that reward. The reward is a lot
1:23:14
of traffic but you have to earn the reward and there's a lot of work involved. And so ideally what we want to
1:23:20
do is follow what we call the 8020 rule when it comes to search engine
1:23:26
optimization and ranking on Google. And what do we mean by the 8020 rule? Well,
1:23:31
80/20 means we're investing 20% of our effort and 80% of the results are
1:23:38
obtained. So, we want to invest 20 and get back 80. That's basically what we mean by 8020. So, for example, if 20% of
1:23:46
our targeted keywords bring in 80% of the traffic, then that's following the 8020 rule. Or 20% of our landing pages
1:23:54
drive 80% of the overall traffic, that's following the 8020 rule. or 20% of our back links pass 80% of our link juice.
1:24:02
That's the 8020 rule. Meaning these targeted keywords, these targeted landing pages, these trying to target
1:24:09
back links using offsite engagement. We want to put in 20% of our effort on
1:24:15
those keywords, landing pages, and back links in return for 80% of the results.
1:24:21
So without further ado, let's get started with the keyword research. Let's
1:24:26
talk about that keyword research for a website with shoes. And and it doesn't really matter what particular product
1:24:35
you have. If you need to rank number one on Google, it all starts with the keywords as I mentioned before. And so
1:24:42
in this example, if you have a website where you sell shoes for kids, you're going to want to be found for certain
1:24:48
keywords. So the obvious keyword here would be shoes for kids. Well, every
1:24:54
keyword that you target has search volume associated with it. So that means
1:25:00
when we talk about search volume, we're talking about how many people on average
1:25:05
type in that keyword or related keyword on Google.com or Google search. And
1:25:11
there's always an average number of searches associated with every keyword. And we call that search volume. How much
1:25:18
search volume? So obviously if we're going to target a keyword, we want to have as much volume as possible.
1:25:24
However, there's always going to be competition for those keywords, meaning
1:25:29
there's always going to be other websites who want to rank number one on Google for the same keywords. And we
1:25:35
call that competition or difficulty. So for every keyword, you're going to have volume and you're going to have
1:25:41
competition or difficulty. And the difficulty ranges as well depending on
1:25:46
the tool you use. And we'll get into that in a minute. But search volume is
1:25:52
how much on average people are typing in that keyword or close variance of that
1:25:57
keyword. And the difficulty is measured in terms of for kids is highly relevant,
1:26:02
has high volume, and low competition, then that's a keyword we want to target. So we always want to focus in on those
1:26:09
three areas. So there's always a trade-off with keywords. So, shoes for kids might have high volume but also
1:26:16
might have high competition or difficulty. If we look for another keyword that's just as relevant, for
1:26:23
example, shoes for children, it may still have high search volume, but the competition or the difficulty may be
1:26:30
lower. And if that's the case, then that may be a better keyword for us to target. Instead of something highly
1:26:38
competitive like shoes for kids, we can focus on another relevant keyword like shoes for children with just as much
1:26:45
volume and lower competition. And the reason why we want lower competition is
1:26:50

1:26:57

1:27:04

1:27:33

1:27:47

2:45:25

2:45:38

4:45:23

4:45:30

4:45:39

4:45:44
meaning of text. You see, search engine processing is attempting to be human.
4:45:50

4:45:57
the words. Similarly, when a search engine goes to your website, it may seek
4:46:02

4:46:08

4:46:14

4:46:20

4:46:25

4:46:30

4:46:38
bigger broader idea for your website the next site signal that we have is site
4:46:43
maps. Now there are two kinds of site maps. There's the site map that is for
4:46:48
humans and there is the site map that are for search engine robots, crawlers
4:46:54
or spiders. The one that is for human is called an HTML sitemap. You've probably
4:47:00
seen these before. The link is generally in the footer of a website. If you click on it, it shows you the major sections
4:47:07
of the website, provides some search functionality, but looking at it as a
4:47:13
human, it shows you the hierarchy of the website and where to find important information. It shows how everything
4:47:20
fits together. Now, there's something else that exists called an XML sitemap. It's
4:47:26
not linked from any page of your website, but exists as an independent file on your server. Now this is
4:47:34
something you can see but it is formatted for search engine spiders using a programming language
4:47:41
called XML. It shows the hierarchy and the priority of each of the URLs of the
4:47:46
website. Every page, every document, every image and it also shows the date
4:47:52
that each page was last updated or changed. So, at this point, we've covered a lot
4:47:58
of things that are important and things that you should be doing when optimizing your onpage content. Now, let's go a
4:48:05
different direction and cover things that you should not be doing. Keyword stuffing, hidden text, repetitive anchor
4:48:12
text, and cloaking. The first one is keyword stuffing. Now, back in the early days of search engine optimization,
4:48:19
people used to increase the instances of words on the page. Now, this is well
4:48:24
before natural language processing. At that time, search engines were looking for occurrences of specific words. Well,
4:48:32
search engines, they're very smart about this. What may have worked 20 years ago or 10 years ago, keyword stuffing does
4:48:39
not work. You're not going to rank better for any given phrase by including it a dozen or more times on the page. In
4:48:47
fact, you might get an over optimization penalty by constantly repeating the same
4:48:53
word over and over. Focus on writing content that engages with your visitors and uses language naturally. Now, the
4:49:01
next one is hidden text. Unfortunately, I still see this. This is when you write content that is solely for search
4:49:07
engines and not for people. Now, typically it is attempted by writing a
4:49:13
lot of repetitive keywords as text, coloring it white and placing it against
4:49:18
a white background. You see, this was developed as another way to add more keyword stuffed text without the user
4:49:25
seeing the overuse of keywords. Now, it didn't work too well in the past and it definitely does not work today. This
4:49:31
tactic backfires in two ways. First, search engines can tell when it's white
4:49:37
text on a white background. It's easy to tell from a computer science point of view. Search engines read the HTML and
4:49:44
in the HTML are the instructions for colors. When you hide text, modern
4:49:50
search engines are smart enough to figure it out, probably better than a human. Now, secondly, it's done to hide
4:49:56
repetitive keyword stuff text, which is the second thing against you. These outdated, unprofessional tactics will
4:50:03
most likely get a website penalized by the search engines. The next one is repetitive anchor text. You may have
4:50:11
followed a link to a page when looking for a business or information and instead of the information you want, you
4:50:17
get a page that doesn't feel like it was written for people. Every sentence is redundant, repetitive, and almost every
4:50:24
keyword is linked even when there doesn't need to be a link. It confuses the flow of the information on the page.
4:50:31
Now again, this used to be a tactic that sometimes would work, but it's no longer
4:50:37
helpful. Search engines and their natural language processing algorithms have advanced significantly. They can
4:50:44
tell when something's not readable. When something is probably intended for machines and rankings, but not for
4:50:49
people, search engines will figure it out. Please don't waste time on redundant links trying to inflate the
4:50:55
relevance of your links and pages. The last thing to cover here is cloaking.
4:51:01
Cloaking is the idea of showing one thing to the search engines and something entirely different to humans.
4:51:07
Now, this is related to the rest of the tactics I just covered. It's something that used to work, but it was expressly
4:51:14
against the search engine guidelines. While it may have worked if the search engines discovered it on your website,
4:51:20
you could have been penalized or dropped from the search engine results entirely. Now we've covered all of the most

5:38:12
engine optimization. We're going to go through a series of questions and I'm going to answer those questions for you.
5:38:17
Okay. So, the first question that you might be asked in an interview is differentiate between do follows and no
5:38:25
follows. Okay. So, if you've taken or listened to my SEO courses on YouTube
5:38:30
for SEO, we we talked a lot about do follows and no follows. And and simply
5:38:36
put, I mean, do follows are just signals to the search engines to follow the link. So, there's a link on site A
5:38:43
pointing to site B. We're going to basically tell Google, Bing, and some of these other search engines, hey, go
5:38:49
ahead and follow that link. Now, a no follow is just the opposite. So, no follow link doesn't allow the search engine crawlers to follow it. So, if we
5:38:56
have a link on our site, site A pointing to site B, we could put a no follow tag
5:39:03
in there. And what that's going to do, it's going to signal to the crawlers,
5:39:08
hey, don't follow this link. So, in the end, if the crawlers don't follow the link, then there's not going to be any
5:39:15
link juice passed. And so Google is not going to give you credit or give that
5:39:20
site credit for having a link pointing to it or pointing to another site or
5:39:26
from another site. And so it's all about linking. So we can control if there's links on our site whether we want the
5:39:32
crawlers to recognize those or not simply with no follow tags. So just a
5:39:39
reminder, link juice is the reputation or equity passed from one website to another. So if you have a link on
5:39:46
another website and that website is of high quality, meaning their page authority, their domain authority is
5:39:51
high, they have a lot of content, you know, they're not spammy, they're really rich, and they're relevant, then you may
5:39:58
want to make sure that the link pointing from that site to your site is a no follow. So that way that Google can
5:40:04
recognize the link from that site to your site and basically that reputation
5:40:09
is going to be passed on to you. Okay? So that's a do follow versus a no follow. And why would we do a no follow?
5:40:16
Well, it depends. It really depends. A lot of social media platforms like Facebook have no follows. If you have a
5:40:23
lot of content, you may not want to be pushing out a lot of do follows. It could actually look bad from an external
5:40:30
linking standpoint. And so a lot of sites are really particular about who they want to pass link juice on to give
5:40:36
credit for the link. So it's a business decision at the end of the day. Okay, there's really no hard fast rule here
5:40:43
except from an SEO perspective. If I have a site and I have a lot of external links pointing outward to other sites.
5:40:50
I'm going to be particular about who I allow the search engine to follow and
5:40:55
what links I allow not to follow. So, here's an example of what they look like. So, do follow is simply just the
5:41:01
href. Notice the no follow has the the tag appended to it, the href tag with a
5:41:08
no follow. So, if the search engine's crawling your site and they see that no
5:41:13
follow there, they're not going to follow that link. And vice versa, if there's a link on another site pointing to yours and there's a no follow there,
5:41:19
you're not going to get credit. The search engines aren't going to pick up that link. Okay, so question two, what is 301 redirect and how is it different
5:41:27
from a 302 redirect? So 301 redirects tell users in the search engine
5:41:33
specifically that an original page has been moved and this is the keyword here permanently. So permanently moved. We're
5:41:40
going to explain that in a minute. So it's just moved from one page to another. And so if we don't have a page
5:41:47
anymore, we have a new page. Let's just say you built a new website with new URLs. You want to make sure the old page
5:41:54
is pointing to the new page with a 301 redirect. So if a 301 redirect is
5:42:01
permanent, then a 302 is temporary. So we want the search engines to recognize
5:42:07
that we have 301 permanent redirects in place. Why? Because if we have
5:42:12
temporary, then it might alert Google to not keep that page in its search engine
5:42:19
rankings because it's temporary. So why would Google want to keep a temporary page or even a page that is pointing to
5:42:26
another page on a temporary basis? So they may remove both pages from its
5:42:31
index. Okay. But if we have something permanent in place, Google may say, "Okay, this page is permanently linking
5:42:38
to another page or redirecting to another page. Therefore, it's stable.
5:42:43
It's permanent. We're going to keep that new page in the index and eventually remove the old page." So really
5:42:50
something permanent is more stable in the eyes of the search engine. Something temporary may not be as stable in the
5:42:56
eyes of say Google and if they don't see it as stable then they may remove both pages from the index. Okay. So the idea
5:43:03
is we want to be found in Google search index and we get it sometimes pages go away for a variety of reasons and if it
5:43:10
does go away just make sure you have a new page for it and that new page is a 301 permanent redirect. Okay. So
5:43:18
question three, why are back links important in SEO? Well, we kind of
5:43:23

5:43:30
from that other website is really relevant and and it has a high page and
5:43:35

5:43:41

5:43:49
the search engines are going to recognize the relationship between the site that has a link pointing to us.
5:43:55
Okay? So it's just going to build our credibility. It's going to increase increase our domain authority. And then
5:44:01
the net effect of that is if we're credible and we have high domain authority, then that's going to increase
5:44:08
the rankings of our pages. And when the pages increase in ranking, then we're
5:44:14
going to get a more of a lion share of the traffic for certain keywords that our pages are found for. And if our
5:44:20
pages are found and getting traffic, then because we have increased rankings, we're likely going to have increased
5:44:25

5:44:32
idea for SEO is remember you have an onpage strategy and an off- page strategy. Building external links is
5:44:39

5:44:45

5:44:52

5:44:59

5:45:05

5:48:29
other words, Google, for example, has two bots. They have the traditional desktop bot and they have a smartphone
5:48:35

5:48:41

5:48:46

5:48:53
meaning the page isn't designed for a smartphone browser or let's just say the
5:48:59

5:49:05

5:49:12

5:49:17
indexed. And so if your website has a responsive design, Google will rank your
5:49:23
website based on its performance on mobile devices. Okay? So you want to make sure that your website is mobile
5:49:30

5:49:42

5:49:56

6:16:51

6:21:10

6:21:15

6:21:29
keywords that appear when a user searches any word in the phrase. Now you can define
6:21:35

6:21:41

6:21:48
precise order, but with some additional words in the beginning or at the end of the query. Okay, so usually these are
6:21:54
sentences. So, you could be, you know, bidding on red Adidas running shoes and
6:22:02

6:22:07
Oregon. Okay, as an example. Okay, so as long as red Adidas running shoes are in order in that keyword phrase, then your
6:22:15

6:22:22
So, exact match are keywords that are triggered only when that keyword and
6:22:27
exactly that keyword phrase is queried. So, if you do an exact match for red
6:22:33
Adidas running shoes and somebody types in only red Adidas running shoes, then
6:22:38
that's an exact match and your ad's going to appear. So, let's take a look at these again. So, you got broad match.
6:22:44
Okay, we got a term cheap smartphone. So if somebody types in smartphone, cheap
6:22:50
phone, smart mobile, phone cheap, any one of those combinations, your ad's going to appear. Now, there's one thing
6:22:56

6:23:04
keyword. For example, let's just say you really want to emphasize the word cheap. Okay, you're selling really inexpensive
6:23:11
smartphones. Okay, not just any smartphone, but an inexpensive smartphone. So you can put a plus sign
6:23:17
in front of cheap. And so if somebody puts in, you know, just smartphone or smart mobile, your ad's not going to
6:23:24

6:23:30

6:23:36

6:23:42

landing page experience. So obviously a higher quality score the better off you are. Okay, a low quality score it's not
6:34:23
going to bode well for you. And so if you have a low quality score, Google actually will tell you which of these
6:34:30

6:34:37
for each of these three components that make up quality score. And I will tell you this, if I were to divide them up in
6:34:44

6:34:51
of quality score. And expected clickthrough rate is basically Google saying look, other advertisers have bid
6:34:56
on this keyword and their clickthrough rate has been historically around say for example 3%. So if you can't get 3%
6:35:05

6:35:11
you're bidding on. Likewise for the landing page, but the landing page experience is a little bit more subjective because the landing page has

6:35:44
to bid higher because quality score times bid equals ad rank. So for every
6:35:52

there are three major things that attract marketers to search engine optimization and in my opinion these
2:19
three things make seo the best traffic source number one unlike paying for ads
2:24
search traffic is free number two organic traffic is typically consistent
2:29
once you're ranking high whereas other mediums like social media and email marketing often result in traffic spikes
2:36
that usually end up fading to nothing and it makes sense because social media networks are designed to surface fresh
2:42
content emails often get marked as read forgotten or land in the spam box whereas search traffic is a result of
2:49
users actively searching for information and the number of searches for a given topic is typically consistent month to
2:56
month and number three you have the opportunity to reach massive audiences you wouldn't have access to otherwise in
3:03
fact as of october 2019 there were nearly 4.39 billion internet users
3:09
around the world and almost 4 billion of those people are google users this is why search engine optimization
3:15
is an 80 billion dollar industry and why marketers from all walks of life are
3:20
adopting and pursuing it today everyone wants their business to get discovered and seo is the perfect way to do that
3:28
now let's briefly talk about how google works and there are two parts to this the first is crawling and indexation and
3:34
these two things are what actually allows google to discover web pages and create their search index so to actually
3:41
attain information google uses crawlers also known as spiders which gather publicly available information from all
3:49
over the web the spiders will start crawling from a list of known urls called seeds
3:54
then they follow the hyperlinks on those pages and crawl those newly discovered pages and this process goes on and on
4:02
allowing them to collect a ton of information they then take all of this data back to google servers to be added
4:08
to their search index and that's what people like you and i are searching through when we key in a query in google
4:15
now if you were to search for something and google returned every result that mentioned your words on the page then
4:20
you'd end up with really bad results this brings us to the second part which is google's ranking algorithm
4:27
google has hundreds of ranking signals and they make tweaks to their algorithm 500 to 600 times per year so to be frank
4:35
no one knows exactly how their algorithm works but they've given us clues and some
4:40
guidelines to better
4:55
are just speculation at best but i do want to cover a few of the most important factors that you'll need to
5:00
understand from a fundamental standpoint first are backlinks backlinks are links
5:06
from a page on one website to another and google has said on their house search works page that if other
5:12
prominent websites link to a page that's proved to be a good sign that information is well trusted
5:19
the easiest way to understand the value of a backlink is to think of them as votes when a page receives a backlink
5:25
it's essentially another website vouching for the content on the page and the more votes you get from credible
5:31
sources the higher the trust and we also studied the effect of backlinks on search traffic and found a clear
5:38
positive correlation between backlinks from unique websites and a page's organic traffic
5:44
second is search intent which represents the reason behind a searches query and if you think of google's goal for search
5:50
their job is to return the most relevant results for any given query so with that
5:55
said you can discover search intent simply by looking at the top ranking pages for the query you want to rank for
6:02
for example if you search for slow cooker recipes you'll see that the search results are mostly blog posts
6:08
with a list of slow cooker recipes so if you try and rank a product page where you're selling a slow cooker you won't
6:15
be matching search intent and therefore you won't rank now if we change the query to just slow
6:20
cooker you'll see that the dominant types of pages are ecommerce category pages so if you try and rank your blog
6:27
post of slow cooker recipes then you probably won't rank because you're not matching search intent this is a
6:33
critical concept to understand and i'll share a simple three-point checklist you can use to determine search intent for
6:39
any query in the next module and third is content depth search engines are made
6:44
up of computer programs so they can't actually read and understand text like you and i would nevertheless google has
6:52
poured billions of dollars into creating sophisticated technology that understands content to a certain degree
6:59
but it's your job as a content creator to provide context about the subject for
7:04

7:10

8:42

8:49

9:01

9:06

9:11

9:17

9:22
keyword by using a keyword research tool like ahrefs keywords explorer for example the query kilometers to miles
9:30
gets searched around 478 000 times per month in the us alone but
9:35

9:42
google has a handy calculator right here that'll solve the searcher's problem so search volume alone can actually be a
9:49
bit misleading which is why it's worth looking at the second checkpoint which is to check the traffic potential of the
9:55

10:00
to rank at the top of google for your keyword let's look at the stats for our seo checklist page in hf site explorer
10:07

10:20

10:26

10:31

10:38
keywords in the top ten so while you may be optimizing your pages for a main keyword your page will
10:44
likely rank for hundreds or even thousands of other relevant keywords and because of that the monthly search
10:51
traffic potential of the topic seo checklist is actually higher than its monthly search volume
10:57
this is what makes traffic potential a much more reliable metric than search volume and the way you determine traffic
11:03

11:10

11:17

11:23

11:28
results page and as you can see our page gets an estimated 5 300 monthly search visits
11:35
from the us alone and we rank for over 1300 keywords making traffic potential
11:41
of this keyword higher than its search volume now it doesn't always work out this way
11:47

11:54

12:28

13:10

13:24

13:30

13:37

13:44

How to analyze search intent
15:40

15:46
to take some time to unpack what it is and how to use it in keyword research
15:51
reason being if you can't match searcher intent then you probably aren't going to rank for your target keywords
15:58

16:04

16:12
any given query and while it might sound like you're trying to satisfy google what you're actually doing is learning
16:19

16:25

16:33

16:39
searchers want probably more than anyone else now analyzing is kind of a jargony word
16:45
but i have a simple three prong formula you can use it's called the three c's of search intent
16:51
the first c is content type content type can usually be categorized into blog posts videos product category
16:59
and landing pages for example the dominant type of pages for the quarry best golf shoes are blog
17:06
posts the second c is content format and this applies more to blog posts and landing
17:12
pages a few common blog formats you'll see are how to's step-by-step tutorials
17:19
list posts and opinion editorials for a landing page that might be something like a tool or calculator
17:26
again for the quarry best golf shoes you'll see that all of the top results are listicles which makes sense because
17:32
the word best implies that a comparison needs to be made and the third c is content angle which
17:39
often depicts the benefit it's basically your hook as to why someone should click and visit your page for best golf shoes
17:47
you'll see that every post has gone with a freshness angle which is evident based on the current year being in the titles
17:53
in my opinion this is the least important and often least consistent among top ranking pages
17:59
now this is just one example of search intent for a keyword let's go through a few more examples to really drill in

18:31

18:37

18:43

33:35

33:40

33:58

34:05

34:25

34:31

41:24

41:31

41:45
in your title url and content for example if you wanted to rank for
41:50

41:57

42:03

42:09

42:14

42:19

42:25

42:30

42:36

42:42

59:56

1:00:03
building is the process of getting other websites to link to a page on your website and these hyperlinks are called
1:00:09
backlinks now while the end result might make sense conceptually and seem simple
1:00:14
the part that most people don't understand and can't seem to get right is this
1:00:20
the process and this ultimately boils down to emailing complete strangers and asking
1:00:26
them to link to you now let's take a quick second to talk about how strange and kind of awkward this might sound so
1:00:33
let's go through a few scenarios and then we'll revisit this definition of link building let's say that you have a marketing blog
1:00:39
and you write about seo and digital marketing now if some random person let's call her sally sent you an email
1:00:46
and said hey can you link to my post on facebook ads it's really good would you
1:00:52
link to her probably not in fact you probably wouldn't even reply or click the link in
1:00:58
her email to actually check and see if her content is as good as she claims
1:01:03
now let's flip the script a bit let's say that you've been following ahrefs youtube channel and blog for some time
1:01:09
you've implemented some of the strategies we've shared and gotten some great results for your site on top of
1:01:15
that you've been using our seo tools for three years now an email pops up in your inbox from
1:01:21
me samo a name and face you might recognize because you've been following our channel and in that email i've asked
1:01:28
you to link to our free backlink checker from your page that lists the 15 best free seo tools would you link to me
1:01:36
maybe now the final scenario let's say your mentor who helped you get started in digital marketing sends you an email and
1:01:43
she asked you to link to a page on her site from a relevant page on yours would you link to her
1:01:49
definitely she helped you get started in digital marketing you obviously trust and respect her and you'd be willing to
1:01:56
bend over backwards for her the point of these scenarios is to show you that the process of link building is actually
1:02:02
very relational and can sometimes take more time than you might like with sally you don't know her you don't
1:02:08
owe her anything you don't trust her she's blindly coming in almost invading
1:02:14
your inbox and asking you for a favor without offering any kind of value in
1:02:19
return in the second scenario when i hypothetically emailed you you knew who i was i had indirectly helped you and
1:02:26
you were a user of a product for years so while we may not have a real-life relationship we're still connected in
1:02:32
some way so the chances of linking to me are probably higher than linking to sally
1:02:38
now when your mentor asked you for a link there's a real relationship there there's a sense of trust respect and
1:02:45
gratitude so of course you would link to her now while you can't and shouldn't try to become friends with everyone just
1:02:52
to get links you'll find that your best links will usually come from relationships that are sparked from
1:02:57
email outreach so let's redefine link building and set the tone for the rest of this module link building is the
1:03:03
process of building relationships with other relevant site owners who want and
1:03:08
will link to your content because it enhances theirs so this definition isn't just about you
1:03:14
getting something it includes relationships relevance and a value exchange all things we'll touch on later
1:03:20
in this module now since effective link building is tough you need to understand why it's worth the effort in short
1:03:27
backlinks are used by search engines like google to help rank web pages and it's been this way since 1998 when
1:03:33
google created page rank page rank is a mathematical formula that judges the value of a page by looking at the
1:03:40
quantity and quality of other pages that link to it and google confirms the importance of backlinks on their house
1:03:46
search works page under their ranking useful pages heading they state if other
1:03:51
prominent websites on the subject link to the page that's a good sign that the information is of high quality
1:03:59
we also found a clear correlation between organic traffic and backlinks from unique websites in our study of
1:04:05
over 1 billion web pages so while getting backlinks may be harder than let's say creating a blog post
1:04:11
they're absolutely critical if you want to rank for competitive phrases and competitive phrases are usually the ones
1:04:18
that will drive the most traffic and revenue for your business now we briefly touched on the main way
1:04:24
of getting backlinks but not all links can or will be obtained through outreach
1:04:29
so in the next lesson we'll talk about three methods to get backlinks as well as the level of difficulty and
1:04:35
effectiveness hey it's ammo and welcome to the second lesson in our link building module in

1:04:41

1:05:40

1:05:46

1:05:53

1:05:58

1:06:05

1:06:12

1:06:17

1:06:25

1:06:30

1:06:39
and in my opinion the risk isn't worth the reward especially if you want to build a business that'll stand the test
1:06:45
of time the final way to get backlinks is to earn them and there are three common ways you can do this the first
1:06:51

1:06:57

1:07:03

1:07:10

1:07:15

1:07:22

1:07:29

1:07:34

1:07:47

1:08:33

1:08:39

1:08:45
say a link from the new york times otherwise backlinks would just be a game of quantity and google search results
1:08:51
would reward the biggest spammers fortunately ranking on google doesn't work that way and quality backlinks are
1:08:58
still a prominent ranking signal so with that said let's talk about the five attributes that make a backlink good the
1:09:05
first attribute is relevance imagine this for a second you're going to visit greece for the first time next month and
1:09:12
you need recommendations for places worth going to now you have a friend that lived in greece for their entire life and
1:09:19
obviously knows every nook and cranny you also have a friend in the u.s who hates traveling and has never been
1:09:25
outside of the states whose opinion would you hold higher obviously your greek friend in the same
1:09:31
way links from a website about travel or greece would hold more weight than links from sites about technology or marketing
1:09:39
because they're more topically relevant and authoritative for example you'll see that this page is ranking number one for
1:09:45
the query how to devein shrimp if we look at their backlinks and also filter by one link per domain we can see their
1:09:52
backlinks from different websites now if you don't have an ahrefs account then you can still see backlinks pointing at
1:09:58
pages using our free backlink checker tool which i'll leave a link to in the description
1:10:03
going back to the backlinks report you'll see this page from wikihow which is called three ways to peel and devein
1:10:10
shrimp so the link is on a very relevant page scrolling down a bit you'll see this
1:10:15
link from a page called shrimp with garlic sauce which again is relevant at the page level but you can also see that
1:10:22
it's relevant at the domain level too just by looking at the domain name slimpalette.com
1:10:28
both of these links are great from a relevant standpoint whereas a link like this one isn't very relevant at all the
1:10:35
page is about firefox 3.5 which is a web browser it comes from a site about video games and computer hardware so an ideal
1:10:42
link would be contextually placed within the body of the content where someone is quite literally recommending or
1:10:49
referencing you alright the next quality of good quality links is authoritativeness
1:10:55
if you're unfamiliar with authority in the context of backlinks it basically represents the so-called link power a
1:11:01
web page has and this relates to how google page rank works as we discussed before both the quantity
1:11:08
and quality of links matter so the more quality links a page gets the more page
1:11:13
rank it earns and the more page rank it has the more authority it can pass to other pages through hyperlinks
1:11:20
for example let's say that page c has two links one from page a and one from page b
1:11:27
page a is stronger than page b and also has fewer outgoing links feed this
1:11:32
information into the pagerank algorithm and you get the page rank of page c now this is obviously a simplified
1:11:38
version of how pagerank works but the key point here is that getting links from high authority pages will likely
1:11:45
have the greatest impact on your rankings now while google doesn't provide page rank or website authority scores we have
1:11:52
two metrics at ahrefs that try to quantify it domain rating is our website authority metric and it represents the
1:11:58
overall strength of a website's backlink profile an url rating is our page level authority metric which represents the
1:12:05
overall strength of a page's backlink profile and you'll find both of these metrics throughout most of our tools giving you
1:12:12
insights on referring pages now we've covered two very important parts of good quality backlinks but what
1:12:18
we haven't talked about yet is the actual link itself so let's break down the anatomy of a
1:12:24
hyperlink and talk about how the different parts relate to seo here's what a link looks like to your
1:12:29
website visitors and if we look at the html code then it would look like this
1:12:35
now there are three basic parts to a link that matter in seo the destination url anchor text and the rel attribute or
1:12:42
lack of one the destination url is simply the url the person will visit when the link is
1:12:48
clicked the second part of a link is the anchor text the anchor text is the clickable word phrase or image attached
1:12:55
to the link so in our example site explorer is the anchor text which is the name of our competitor analysis tool
1:13:02
google uses anchor text to better understand what a page is about and what terms it should rank for but building
1:13:09
lots of links with keyword rich anchors is an example of a link scheme and may result in a google penalty as it looks
1:13:16
unnatural for example if you had a post on the best golf balls and had 100 links
1:13:21
pointing to it where the anchor texts were all best golf balls then it would look and be quite unnatural
1:13:28
people often use anchors such as the company's brand name the title of the page the url or phrases like click here
1:13:36
and here's some proof if we look at the anchors of backlinks pointing to our data study on featured snippets you'll
1:13:41
see varying anchor texts like ahrefs old studies hr study research and even
1:13:48
specific stats like 12.3 percent of search queries and 99.58 percent and so
1:13:54
on in fact there are only 16 websites that have linked to us using the anchor text featured snippet
1:14:01
with most earned links you have very little or no control over the anchor text so over optimization isn't
1:14:08
something you really need to worry about and the last part of the link we'll talk about is the rel attribute some links
1:14:14
contain a rel attribute which is intended to tell crawlers about the relationship between the linking page
1:14:20
and the linked page and the three rel values that you should know about when it comes to link building are nofollow ugc and sponsored
1:14:29
historically nofollow links told google that the linking page would rather not associate themselves with the linked
1:14:35
page and for that reason google didn't transfer authority through those links but then google added a couple other rel
1:14:42
values ugc which stands for user generated content and sponsored which
1:14:47
signifies an ethical paid link they also announced that going forward they would look at these link attributes
1:14:53
as hints meaning they may pass value through them at their discretion now if a link doesn't have any of these
1:15:00
rel values then it will be called a followed link meaning the link can pass page rank and help boost your rankings
1:15:08
seeing as this is still relatively new i'd recommend focusing on building followed links although that's only
1:15:14
partially within your control now it's important to note that nofollow in ugc links aren't bad it's just that
1:15:20
followed links are proven to pass authority one final thing i want to touch on is link placement
1:15:27
prominent links are more likely to be clicked and it's believed that google takes this into account when determining
1:15:32
how much authority a link transfers for instance an editorial link is more
1:15:37
likely to be clicked than a link in the footer so all else being equal the former will be better than the latter
1:15:44
so to summarize an ideal link would come from a relevant and authoritative page
1:15:49
where the link is followed it would have a descriptive anchor and be placed contextually within editorial content
1:15:56
but the truth is a lot of this is out of your control what is in your control is how you spend
1:16:02
your time building links by using these five attributes to help qualify prospects or people that are worth
1:16:09
contacting you'll spend your time building links that will actually move the needle

1:34:09

1:34:17

1:34:23

1:34:30

1:36:28

1:36:35

1:36:42

1:36:48

1:37:12

1:37:20

1:37:26

1:37:32

1:37:38

1:37:44

1:37:50

1:37:56

1:38:02

1:38:09

1:38:15

1:38:22

1:43:27
hey it's ammo and welcome to the final module in ahrefs seo course for beginners throughout the next two
What is technical SEO and why its important
1:43:33
lessons we're going to be talking about technical seo and technical seo is the process of optimizing your website to
1:43:40
help search engines find understand and index your pages now for beginners technical seo doesn't
1:43:48
need to be all that technical and for that reason this module will be focused on the basics so you can perform regular
1:43:54
maintenance on your site and ensure that your pages can be discovered and indexed by search engines let's get started all
1:44:02
right so let's talk about why technical seo is important at the core basically
1:44:07
if search engines can't properly access read understand or index your pages then
1:44:12
you won't rank or even be found for that matter so to avoid innocent mistakes like removing yourself from google's
1:44:19
index or diluting a page's backlinks i want to discuss four things that should help you avoid that
1:44:25
first is the no index meta tag by adding this piece of code to your page it's
1:44:30
telling search engines not to add it to their index and you probably don't want to do that and this actually happens
1:44:36
more often than you might think for example let's say you hire design inc to create or redesign a website for
1:44:43
you during the development phase they may create it on a sub-domain on their own site so it actually makes sense for
1:44:50
them to know index the site they're working on but what often happens is after you've approved the design they'll
1:44:55
migrate it over to your domain but they often forget to remove them at a no
1:45:00
index tag and as a result your pages end up getting removed from google search index or never making it in
1:45:08
now there are times when it actually makes sense to no index certain pages for example our authors pages are no
1:45:14
indexed because from an seo perspective these pages provide very little value to
1:45:19
search engines but from a user experience standpoint it can be argued that it makes sense to be there some
1:45:26
people may have their favorite authors on a blog and want to read just their content generally speaking for small sites you
1:45:33
won't need to worry about no indexing specific pages just keep your eye out for no index tags on your pages
1:45:39
especially if after a redesign the second point of discussion is robots.txt
1:45:45
robots.txt is a file that usually lives on your root domain and you should be able to access it at yourdomain.com
1:45:53
robots.txt now the file itself includes a set of rules for search engine crawlers and
1:45:59
tells them where they can and cannot go on your site and it's important to note that a website can have multiple robots
1:46:06
files if you're using sub domains for example if you have a blog on domain.com
1:46:11
then you'd have a robots.txt file for just the root domain but you might also have an ecommerce store that lives on
1:46:18
store.domain.com so you could have a separate robots file for your online store
1:46:24
that means that crawlers could be given two different sets of rules depending on the domain they're trying to crawl
1:46:30
now the rules are created using something called directives and while you probably don't need to know what all
1:46:35
of them are or what they do there are two that you should know about from an indexing standpoint
1:46:41
the first is user agent which defines the crawler that the rules apply to and the value for this directive will be the
1:46:48
name of the crawler for example google's user agent is named googlebot and the
1:46:53
second directive is disallow this is a page or directory on your domain that you don't want the user agent to crawl
1:47:01
for example if you set the user agent to googlebot in the disallow value to a slash you're telling google not to crawl
1:47:08
any pages on your site not good now if you were to set the user agent to an asterisk that means your rules should
1:47:15
apply to all crawlers so if your robot's file looks something like this then it's
1:47:21
telling all crawlers please don't crawl any pages on my site while this might
1:47:26
sound like something you would never use there are times when it makes sense to block certain parts of your site or to
1:47:32
block certain crawlers for example if you have a wordpress website and you don't want your wp-admin
1:47:39
folder to be crawled then you can simply set the user agent to all crawlers and set the disallow value to slash wp admin
1:47:47
now if you're a beginner i wouldn't worry too much about your robots file but if you run into any indexing issues
1:47:53
that need to be troubleshooted robots.txt is one of the first places i check
1:47:59
alright the next thing to discuss are sitemaps sitemaps are usually xml files and they list the important urls on your
1:48:05
website so these can be pages images videos and other files insight maps help
1:48:12
search engines like google to more intelligently crawl your site now creating an xml file can be complicated
1:48:18
if you don't know how to code and it's almost impossible to maintain manually but if you're using a cms like wordpress
1:48:26
there are plugins like yoast and rank math which will automatically generate sitemaps for you to help search engines
1:48:32
find your sitemaps you can use the sitemap directive in your robots file and also submit it in google search
1:48:38
console next up are redirects a redirect takes visitors and bots from one url to
1:48:45
another and their purpose is to consolidate signals for example let's say you have two pages on your website
1:48:51
on the best golf balls an old one at domain.com bestgolfballs2018
1:48:57
and another at domain.com best golf balls seeing as these are highly relevant to
1:49:03
one another it would make sense to redirect the 2018 version to the current version and by consolidating these pages
1:49:11
you're telling search engines to pass the signals from the redirected url to the destination url
1:49:17
and the last point i want to talk about is the canonical tag a canonical tag is a snippet of html code that looks like
1:49:24
this its purpose is to tell search engines what the preferred url is for a page and
1:49:30
this helps to solve duplicate content issues for example let's say your website is
1:49:35
accessible at both http colon double slash yourdomain.com
1:49:40
and https colon double slash yourdomain.com and for whatever reason
1:49:47
you weren't able to use a redirect these would be exact duplicates but by setting a canonical url you're telling search
1:49:54
engines that there's a preferred version of the page as a result they'll pass signals such as
1:50:00
links to the canonical url so they're not diluted across two different pages
1:50:05
now it's important to note that google may choose to ignore your canonical tag looking back at the previous example if
1:50:11
we set the canonical tag to the unsecure http page google would probably choose the secure
1:50:18
https version instead now if you're running a simple wordpress site you shouldn't have to worry about
1:50:24
this too much cmss are pretty good out of the box and will handle a lot of these basic technical issues for you
1:50:31
so these are some of the foundational things that are good to know when it comes to indexing which is arguably the
1:50:37
most important part in seo because again if your pages aren't getting indexed
1:50:42
nothing else really matters now we won't really dig deeper into this because you'll probably only have to worry about
1:50:48
indexing issues if and when you run into problems instead we'll be focusing on technical seo best practices to keep
1:50:56
your website in good health hey it's ammo and welcome to the final lesson in this module and actually it's
What are technical SEO best practices
1:51:03
the last lesson in ahrefs seo course for beginners in this lesson we're going to
1:51:08
go through some technical seo best practices so you can keep your site in good health let's get started so the
1:51:15
first thing you should do is ensure that your site structure follows a logical hierarchy site structure is simply the
1:51:21
way you organize content on your website you can think of it like a mind map at the top you'd have your home page
1:51:28
then you'd probably have main topics that branch out from your home page like your services page your blog and about
1:51:34
page then from these main topics you'd probably have even more branches to other pages
1:51:40
these branches represent internal links which are just links from one page on your site to another and they help
1:51:46
search engines understand the relationship between these pages site structure also helps search engines
1:51:52
to crawl your pages more efficiently which is why having a logical hierarchy is important
1:51:58
now what we've talked about is pretty basic stuff and you may already be doing this but it can get more complex as you
1:52:05
add more pages to your site like blog posts category pages or product pages we
1:52:11
have a full video on how to use internal links to rank higher on google so i'll link that up for you in the description
1:52:17
alright the second thing is to ensure your pages don't load slow as you may know pagespeed has been a
1:52:23
confirmed ranking factor for desktop search since 2010 and in 2018 google
1:52:29
announced that they'd be using page speed in mobile search rankings now you don't need to obsess over every
1:52:35
millisecond it takes for your page to load google says the speed update as we're calling it will only affect pages
1:52:42
that deliver the slowest experience to users and will only affect a small percentage of quarries
1:52:49
so bottom line you don't want your pages to load slow and there are two very basic things that
1:52:55
i think every website should do the first is to cache your website's content
1:53:00
caching is basically a way to temporarily store copies of files so it can be delivered to visitors in a more
1:53:06
efficient way and most web hosting companies that i've come across have caching features
1:53:12
and the second thing you can do is compress your images compressing images makes your file sizes
1:53:18
smaller and smaller files load faster you can use a tool like short pixel which has both a web interface and a
1:53:25
wordpress plugin now if you want to take page speed a step further then it can get quite technical and complex
1:53:32
so we actually created a full tutorial on how to speed up a wordpress website using cloudflare and a wordpress plugin
1:53:39
so i'll leave a link to that in the description and the final thing i want to talk about is to do your best to stay on top of
1:53:45
around 50 potential seo errors trust me it's not as bad as it sounds
1:53:51
there are potentially hundreds of technical seo issues that can and some will definitely happen to your site some
1:53:58
of these things include pages becoming broken that still have internal links pointing at them
1:54:04
orphan pages which are pages on your site that have no incoming internal links
1:54:09
and these are great because it can make it tough for search engines to actually discover them duplicate content issues and redirect
1:54:16
chains to name a few now there's no point in me going through 50 different potential issues because
1:54:22
it'll only matter to you if you run into them so what i recommend you do is run scheduled website audits on your site
1:54:30
and a website audit will give you a full analysis of potential issues that could be harming your website's seo
1:54:36
performance if you're an ahrefs user you can do that using our site audit tool and even if

8:55:15

8:55:24

8:55:38

8:56:04

8:56:13

8:56:20
then it's going to count as a goal okay and then the fourth type of goal in
8:56:25

8:56:31

8:56:37

SEO Interview Questions And Answers
11:26:47
might be asking interview is differentiate between do follows and no
11:26:52
follows okay so if you take in or listen to my SEO courses on YouTube for SEO we
11:26:59
we talked a lot about do follows and no follows and and simply put I mean do
11:27:04
follows are just signals to the search engines to follow the link so there's a
11:27:09
link on site a pointing to site B we're gonna basically tell Google Bing and
11:27:15
some of these other search engines hey go ahead and follow that link now I know file is just the opposite so no follow
11:27:20
link doesn't allow the search engine crawlers to follow it so if we have a link on our site site a pointing to site
11:27:28
B we could put a nofollow tag in there and what that's going to do it's going to signal to the Crawlers hey don't
11:27:36
follow this link so in the end of the Crawlers don't fall follow the link then there's not going to be any link juice
11:27:43
passed and so Google is not going to give you credit or give that site credit
11:27:48
for having a link pointing to it or pointing to another site or from another
11:27:54
site and so it's all about linking so we can control if there's links on our site
11:27:59
whether we want the Crawlers to recognize those or not simply with no
11:28:04
follow tags so just a reminder link juice is the reputation or Equity pass
11:28:09
from one website to another so if you have a link on another website and that
11:28:15
website is of high quality meaning their page Authority their domain Authority is high they have a lot of content you know
11:28:21
they're not spammy they're really rich and they're relevant then you may want to make sure that the link pointing from
11:28:27
that site to your site is a no follow so that way that Google can recognize the link from that site to your site and
11:28:34
basically that reputation is going to be passed on to you okay so that's a do follow versus a nofollow and why would
11:28:42
we do a no follow well it just pens it really depends a lot of social media
11:28:48
platforms like Facebook have no follows if you have a lot of content you may not want to be pushing out a lot of do
11:28:54
follows it could actually look bad from an external linking standpoint and so a
11:28:59
lot of sites are really particular about who they want to pass link choose onto and give credit for the link so it's a
11:29:06
business decision at the end of the day there's really no hard fast rule here except from an SEO perspective if I have
11:29:13
a site and I have a lot of external links pointing outward to other sites I'm going to be particular about who I
11:29:20

Content Workflow
1:00:40
section is probably one of my favorite ones and one that everybody asked me for, which is content workflow. What I
1:00:46
mean here is how to generate highquality content using AI that's going to help you rank, rank for more keywords, get
1:00:54
organic traffic, and turn you into the topical authority figure. I want to be very clear here. My intention here is to
1:01:00
use AI as an extension, not as a complete replacement of you. I'm not wanting to ram write spammy content. I
1:01:07
want to make that very very clear. So also, search engines don't penalize AI
1:01:13
content. They only penalize lowquality content. I think we've been through that already. But the thing is that all
1:01:19
spammy content looks AI, right? But not all AI content is spammy. So, as long as
1:01:24
you create content with the want and the need to add a lot more value, you're going to be just fine. Obviously, some
1:01:31
things slip through the cracks. There's some websites that are 100% AI generated and for some reason they're ranking
1:01:37
really well. But my recommendation is don't try to copy them because it probably won't work for you. SEO is a
1:01:43
bit weird like that. And if you are doubting if I'm actually uh correct with this whether or somebody says and tells
1:01:50

1:02:10

1:02:34

1:02:41

1:02:47

1:02:52

1:02:58

1:03:05

1:03:22

1:03:36

1:03:42
internet. This isn't dumbing down your content. This is just making it simple. So, don't over complicate it and use
1:03:49

Link Building
2:18:07
The next section that we're going to touch on is link building or back linking. This seems to be the black
2:18:12
magic of SEO. People either run away with it, run away from it because it can get a little bit scary, or they just
2:18:17
don't want to touch it because they don't know how to do it. And I think it'd be summarized in really four main
2:18:23
things that I've got here. The first one is I believe there are two main ways to
2:18:28
get some backlinks. Sure, there are more, but these are the main two. You can either do it yourself by doing the
2:18:33
manual outreach, trying to do guest post, partnerships, PR, local outreach. This takes some
2:18:40
time. Yes, you can automate this, like automate the manual or the outreach, but
2:18:45
I've seen some absolute horror stories when you do that. So, if
2:18:51
you're going to do your own backlinking, be careful. And in a second, I'm going to show you how to get started with
2:18:57
that. And number two is outsource it to a trusted entity. The dirty little secret of SEO is that any agency that
2:19:04
you've hired, there's probably a 99% chance that they just bought the backlink from someone else, another
2:19:10
website that does that only or another agency that does that because the truth is that good backlinking takes some
2:19:16
time. You need the connections. You need to be have a bit of a network of websites that you can reach out to. And
2:19:21
if you don't have that, it can be very difficult. I buy backlinks all the time. Just make sure you do it from reputable
2:19:27
sources. Again, I'm going to show you a couple of sources that I recommend. I buy links all the time and it works
2:19:32
great when done correctly. The main thing that you need to know is that quality will always beat quantity,
2:19:40
right? So, one relevant backlink from a high reputable website beats 100 spammy
2:19:45
back links. If you've been in this space for long enough, you might have seen an ad or somebody might have approached you saying, "Hey, I can get you a,000 back
2:19:52
links for a hundred bucks or $1,000." If that's the case, politely run the other
2:19:58
way. The thing here is that if your website gets associated with really bad quality backlinks or websites, then your
2:20:05
website's just going to be one of those bad quality websites. Relevance is also key here. You want to
2:20:11
aim for sites within your industry, locality, or at least your niche. For
2:20:17
example, if you have a website that is all about how to train dogs and you provide that as a service, maybe don't
2:20:23
get a link from a website that sells computer gaming gear. It just doesn't make any contextual relevance. So, some
2:20:29
quick red flags to avoid is if somebody comes to you with a cheap link building
2:20:34
package, it's not to say that it's always going to be bad if it's cheap, but that should be a red flag for you to
2:20:40
really do the due diligence and check the quality of those links. Again, irrelevant sites with zero opportunity
2:20:45
do not get those. And if a website has a sudden spike in backlinks and it wasn't natural, there's an issue there. At
2:20:52
least there's something that you need to dive in further. So, all well and good. How do we get our first set of backlinks
2:20:58
if we don't want to pay for them? Well,
2:21:03
a very simple and easy strategy that you can do is get yourself on featured.com.
2:21:09

2:21:16
matter experts. They ask questions and if the subject matter expert answers that questions in detail, they'll get
2:21:23
sourced and get a backlink in return. I've done it many times and got a few free backlinks that are high quality.

2:21:35

Houston, Google shows a map with three business  listings at the top. Those are not websites. Those  
0:55
are Google business profiles. And here's what  matters. 60 to 70% of clicks go to those top  
1:01
three map positions. So if you're ranked fourth,  you're on page two. You're invisible. No one is  
1:06
scrolling down to find you. My favorite joke in  SEO, where's the best place to hide a dead body?   Page two of Google's search. This is why local  SEO is a completely different game than regular  
1:16
SEO. In regular SEO, you're trying to rank your  website's URLs. But in local SEO, you're trying to  
1:21
rank your Google business profile. And Google uses  three main factors to decide which businesses show  
1:27
up in those top three spots. Proximity, relevance,  and authority. Let me show you exactly how those  
1:33
three factors work. These three glasses represent  three businesses that are all trying to rank their  
1:38
Google business profile. Now, I mentioned three  important categories to build that rank. We have   trust, we have authority, and we have proximity.  Now, proximity is how far away the searcher is  
1:51
from your particular business. So for this first  one, maybe the searcher is pretty far away.  
1:56
For the second one, the searcher is quite a bit  closer. And for the third business, the searcher   is in the business's doorstep. Now our second  category is relevance. How much relevance does  
2:06
each one of these businesses have? Our third  business, not very much relevance. They have   a very small website, handful of pages. Second  business, same thing. Not very much relevance,  
2:14
handful of pages. The third business, they watch  this video, they built a massive amount of topical  
2:20
relevance. And finally, we have authority. The  first business, they have a couple of simple   links from some blog posts, but you know what?  That's enough for their glass to overflow, from  
2:29
them to rank. Second business, they spent a little  bit more effort. They got a little bit more links,   and they're also overflowing and ranking. Now, our  third business, they have a long way to go, as you  
2:38
can see. And they've done that by joining chambers  of commerce, by sponsoring local sports teams,   by doing everything they need to do to make sure  their glass overflows also. and they can overcome  
2:47
that massive penalty by being simply too far  away. Now, here's the good news about all of this.  
2:53
Most of your local competitors are doing the bare  minimum. You're trying to outrank Joe the plumber  
2:58
who uses Yahoo to figure out where to go to log  into the Google business profile. They filled out   their Google business profile once 3 years ago  and they called it dumb. They have one category  
3:08
when Google allows 10. They have zero services  listed when they should have 30. their glasses  
3:13
are barely half full because they're ignoring two  of the three factors, the only two factors they  
3:18
can actually control. That's why it can be so easy  to outrank established businesses, even if they've  
3:23
been around for decades. They're not playing the  game. They don't even know there's a game to play.   So, if you understand these three factors and  you build your website and your Google business  
3:31
profile to maximize the relevance and authority,  the two you can control, you can rank a business  
3:36

3:42
posts. Any SEO agency pitching you on weekly blog  posts, run away from them. Don't walk. You're not  
3:47
trying to get traffic from people in other cities  reading your content. Every single page on your   local business website exists for one reason, to  help your Google business profile rank higher in  
3:57

4:29

4:39

4:47

4:53

6:29

6:39

6:57

7:02
three massive mistakes in their Google business  profile and it's going to keep them invisible.   And I've seen the same pattern in over 500 GBP  audits. Now, the first mistake is categories.  
7:13
Most businesses I look at choose one category.  They're primary and they just stop there. But   Google allows you to choose up to 10 categories.  And here's why that matters. Every single category  
7:22
you add is another search term that Google might  show you for. If you're a plumber and you only   have plumber as your category, you're missing  out on searches for drainage service and gas  
7:31
installation service. Typically, we want two  to four categories minimum as long as they're   relevant. We can go a lot more as long as it  makes sense for your business. So, how do we  
7:41
choose the right categories? I like to use a  tool called GMBB Everywhere. It makes it very,   very easy to do this. Let me show you exactly  how. So GMBB Everywhere is a Chrome plugin. So  
7:50
I have it installed. That's why we see all these  boxes. And once we do a search on maps.google.com,  
7:56
you can see I search for plumber Houston. I can  come to one of these and I can hit find more. That   opens up this helpful category finder. So it's  going to start on the top by showing me all the  
8:05
categories that this business has chosen for their  GBP and how many GBPs have that category. One and  
8:11
a half million used plumber and then we have air  conditioning contractor etc etc. But here's what  
8:16
makes this so valuable in choosing the best GBP  categories for your business. Right below that we  
8:21
have related categories. So we can see one and a  half million plumbers. We have 15,000 that chose  
8:26
draining service. 110,000 chose plumbing supply  store. We have plumbers merchant. 60,000 chose  
8:32
septic system, septic tank service, and another  60 heating contractor etc etc etc. So doing this,

8:43

8:48

8:54
categories. Between GMBB everywhere and this  prompt, you're going to have the right categories   chosen in like 5 minutes. So that's mistake  number one fixed. Here's that prompt on screen.
9:07
Now, you do have to be careful. AI has a  tendency to just make up GBP categories. So,   it can be helpful to grab a long list of all of  the categories and give that to AI and tell it  
9:16
to choose from the list. So, the second mistake  is services. Most businesses have maybe one, two,  
9:22
maybe five services listed if someone told  them it mattered, it was super important,   but you should have at least 20 services listed  on your Google profile. Why 20? Because every  
9:32
service you list is another signal to Google about  what you actually do. And in competitive markets,   you might actually need 30, 40, or more services  to compete. So, here's what's different from  
9:41
categories. Services need to be categorized,  optimized by which category they're most relevant   to. So, under your plumber category, you're going  to list things like water heater replacement,  
9:50
pipe repair, or leak detection. Google  is looking at whether your services   semantically match your categories. If they  do, that's a relevant signal. If they don't,  
9:58
you're confusing the algorithm. Remember,  Google is just math. The great thing about   services is it's a free box. You can type  whatever you want in. Be creative. Here  
10:07
is an excellent prompt to help you generate  services based on the categories you have.
10:15
Now, the third mistake is a simple one. It's  leaving boxes empty on your GBP. Google gives  
10:21
you a business description field, an attribute  section, a product section, services, which we   just covered, photos, posts. Most businesses fill  out their name, address, phone number. Maybe they  
10:29
upload a logo and leave a lot of the rest blank.  So, here's what you need to understand. Google's   algorithm is looking at completion signals. A  fully completed profile signals that this is an  
10:38
active, legitimate business. An empty profile  signals that maybe this business doesn't exist   anymore, or maybe it's spam, or maybe the business  owner doesn't care. None of those are good. So,  
10:48
you need to fill out every single box.  Your business description should target   750 characters. That's the maximum that Google  allows. Use all of it. photos. Put at least 20  
11:00
photos on their GBP. Exterior photos, interior  photos, team photos, work in progress photos.   Google wants to see that you're a real business.  If you take these photos with your phone, they're  
11:08
going to be geotagged automatically. GBP posts.  I'll show you how to automate this in a minute.   You should be doing that. Attributes. Check every  attribute box that applies. If it doesn't apply,  
11:17
still check it, but check no. Veteranowned,  womanowned, except credit cards, free estimates,   ADA compliant, bathroom, whatever is relevant.  This entire audit, categories, services,  
11:25
filling out every box should take you about a half  hour. And it's going to put you ahead of 90% of   your local competitors immediately. Honestly,  80% of local businesses can get to a point  
11:35
where they have enough top 3% to be a six-figure  business just by doing these basic things. Now,  
11:40
I'm going to put the full GBP audit guide we use  every day at my agency in the school community.   A link is in the description. There are nearly  3,000 SEO professionals there, and my team and I  
11:50
help answer questions about SEO. Now, your Google  business profile is only half of the equation. If  
11:55
your website doesn't match what you put in your  GBP, Google won't build enough relevance for  
12:00
competitive market. Google is checking if your  website and GBP belong to the same business.   If you fail this test, you're not going to rank  in a competitive market. Your GBP landing page,  
12:09
that's what I refer to as the URL you put in  your website field of your Google business   profile. For most single location businesses,  it's just your homepage. Google is looking at  
12:18
that page to verify that your website and your  GBP are the same business. If they don't match,  
12:24
Google assumes one of them is fake or that you  don't know. So, here are seven consistency signals  
12:30
that page must have. I'll show them on screen  here while I walk through. First, your title tag   must include your primary category and your city  name. It should be something like Houston plumber  
12:39
same day service brand name. I analyzed over a 100  local businesses a couple months ago and over 60%  
12:44
of them had the word home or just their business  name as the title tag. They're making it easy for   you to outrank them. Okay. Second, your H1 needs  to match. It has to include your primary category  
12:53
and your city name. Third, you want to have a  Google Maps embed of your GBP location on the  
12:58
page. Google makes this super easy to do. Fourth,  your secondary categories and that core service   should be mentioned ideally in the subheading.  Fifth, you need to have a review widget to display  
13:08
Google Business reviews on your homepage. Sixth,  your address needs to match your GBP address   character for character. And seventh, your phone  number needs to match character for character.  
13:17
I'll even give you a bonus eighth to make sure you  have local business schema on that homepage. Also,   these seven elements create what Google calls  consistency signals. The more consistent your  
13:27
website is with your GP, the more Google trusts  that they belong to the same business. Now,   here's something that most people don't know.  Google invented the transformer technology back  
13:35
in 2017. That's the same tech that powers chat GPT  and every other AI you've ever heard of. In fact,  
13:41
the T in chat GPT actually stands for transformer.  Both Google search and chat GPT care about the  
13:47
same thing, consistency. When someone asks Chat  GPT for a plumber recommendation in Houston,  
13:52
it's checking very similar signals to what  Google is checking. Is the business information   consistent? Does the address match? Are the  services clearly listed? And here's why chat  
14:01
GPT optimization builds even more trust  than Google. When you show up on Google,   it's a vote of trust from the algorithm. But when  chat GPT recommends you, that feels like a friend  
14:10
recommending someone. It's personal. It's trusted.  So when a customer finds you on both Google   and you're recommended by Chat GPT, man, those  customers are sold before they even call you. And  
14:20
that's what this whole system is built on. Using  your website to prove to Google and to AI tools   that your business is to be trusted. All right. So  those are the basics. Now, I want to finish this  
14:30

14:40
is watching for activity signals. Businesses that  post regularly, respond to reviews, upload photos,   active profiles rank higher than dormant ones.  It's as simple as that. But I know nobody wants
