15:29
posts. Most businesses post once and forget about  it for 6 months. We're going to post every single   week with one prompt that generates 52 posts,  one for every week of the year. Schedule all 52  
15:38

15:47
but we consistently see more rank movement  when we do weekly geote photos than we do   non-geeote. This is almost certainly because most  smartphones will automatically geoteag photos. So,  
15:58
Google is expecting to see photos with meta data.  Plus, tools like Lead Snap will automatically  
16:03
geotag on upload now, so there's no real extra  work involved. Okay. And third, AI powered review  
16:08
responses. This takes roughly 25 seconds to set up  and it handles all review responses automatically.

16:22
schedule the post, and then your GBP stays active  all year without you having to touch it. So,   that is the complete foundation, GBP optimized,  landing page optimized, management automated. Now,  
16:32
in the next 10 minutes or so, I know this video is  going long, but I promised a full guide. I'm going   to show you the website structure that got that  Plano plumber from position 17 to 2.35. And it's  
16:42
nothing like what most SEO agencies are doing. I  call it the core 30. And here's why. If you have  
16:47
three to four categories and 20 to 30 services  on your GBP, you're going to end up with about   30 pages of content. One homepage, three to four  category pages, and 25 to 30 service pages comes  
16:58
to around 30 pages. And these 30 pages create the  foundation of topical relevance that Google needs  
17:03
to see before it will rank you in competitive  markets. So, let me tell you exactly how this   works. The homepage is your GBP landing page. We  already covered what needs to be on that page,  
17:12
all eight consistency elements. But here's what  most people miss. The homepage also needs to do  
17:17
more than just mention your secondary categories.  So if your primary category is plumber and your   secondary categories are drainage service  and gas installation service, each of those  
17:25
secondary categories gets an H2, a subheading on  your homepage. Under that subheading, write 50 to  
17:31
100 words about that category. What it is, why  customers need it, what services fall under it,   how good you are at doing it. And then this  is critical, link from that paragraph to a  
17:41
dedicated category page. Not a navigation link,  not a footer link, an editorial link, a link that  
17:47
appears in the context, in the paragraph that  tells Google exactly what that page is going to   be about. Because here's what most people don't  understand. Navigation links and footer links  
17:55
barely pass any authority. Google knows these are  just site structure. They're not endorsements.  
18:00
Editorial links, links in your content pass real  authority. Google sees those and understands that  
18:06
this page is recommending this other page. So from  your homepage, you're going to have three to four   editorial links going to your category pages. Now,  let's look at a category page. The target keyword  
18:16
for your category pages is the category name plus  the city name, drainage service, Houston. That's   going to go in your title tag. That's going to go  in your H1, your primary heading. And then on that  
18:25
category page, you're going to list the services  that are most relevant to that category. Each one  
18:30
gets an H2 subheading. You're going to write 50 to  100 words about that specific service. And you're  
18:37
going to link from that paragraph to a dedicated  service page. So from each category page,   you might have 5 to 10 editorial links to the  service pages. Are we seeing the pattern here?  
18:46
Homepage links to the category pages. Category  pages link to the service pages. It mirrors your  
18:51
GBP structure exactly. Google looks at this and it  sees all of these internal links. a comprehensive,  
18:57
wellorganized website that matches exactly what  you already told it in your Google business  
19:03
profile. Okay, so let's look at a service  page. The target keyword is the service name   plus the city name. Water heater replacement  Houston, emergency plumber Houston. Title tag,  
19:12
primary heading, same pattern. And then you write  detailed content about that specific service. Why  
19:18
customers need it, what it includes, how long  it takes, what to expect. This is where you   get specific. This is not generic plumbing advice.  This is not five ways to tell if your water heater  
19:27
needs to be replaced. This is specific information  about this exact service in this exact city. Now,  
19:33
here's the question everyone asks.  How do you write 30 pages of unique,   high-quality content without spending weeks on it?  Okay, you're already using AI to write content.  
19:41
I certainly hope you are at least. But here's  what most people get wrong. Google doesn't care   if content is written by AI or by humans. Google  cares if content is helpful. And most AI content  
19:52
isn't helpful because it's generic. It's vague.  It's walls of text with no formatting, no images,  
19:57
no personality. Let me give you the prompt we  use to generate better content for local SEO.
20:18
But you still need a human editor to go through  and add real business personality and voice.  
20:24
Images, client photos are best, AI generated  works, callouts, tables, proper formatting,   headers, bullet points, short paragraphs, internal  links connecting the pages together. Because  
20:32
here's what Google is actually evaluating. They're  looking at your pages on the most recent version   of mobile Chrome. If your page looks like a wall  of AI slop with no images and no formatting,  
20:43
Google will think, "Boy, this page looks like a  wall of AI slop." So, build the content with AI,  
20:48
but make sure it looks like a real website that  a real business would have. When you're done with   the core 30, you have 30 pages of content that  matches your GBP categories and services exactly.  
20:58
They all use target keywords consistently. They  link together in a clear hierarchy. They look   professional and well-designed. This is proof  to Google that you are comprehensive and you  
21:07
are legitimate. This is what topical relevance  looks like. 30 pages all proving you actually   do what you say you do. This is filling up the  glass, the relevance class that we talked about  
21:16
at the beginning of this video. But even perfect  content won't rank without one more component.   We still need authority. After AI took over the  internet, Google changed how it evaluates content  
21:26
quality. So here's what actually works now. Way  back in 1999, Sergey Brin and Larry Pageige had  
21:33
an insight that would lead to a multi- trillion  dollar company. You can read about their Stanford   PhD dissertation all about this tonight if you're  having trouble sleeping. But the insight was  
21:43
simple. Quality websites don't link to spam. If  a trusted website links to your page, it's a vote  
21:48
of confidence. Your page is probably pretty  good. That insight built Google's algorithm,  
21:53
and it's still the foundation of how Google's  algorithm works today. But here's what changed   in 2023. In November, AI content started flooding  the internet. Millions of pages of AI generated  
22:05
content appeared overnight and most of it was  garbage. Generic, unhelpful, lowquality slop.  
22:11
Google needed a way to separate the AI slop from  content that was actually useful. And the answer   was the same as it's always been. Links. If  you have AI generated content on your site,  
22:21
which you should because AI makes this process  possible, you're going to need external links   proving the content is quality. Without links,  Google has no way to verify that your content is  
22:31
trustworthy and worthy of its searchers spending  time on it. With links, Google sees that other   sites trust your content enough to link to it.  So, for the core 30, you're going to need two  
22:40
types of links. The first type I call this is not  AI slop links. These are medium quality external  
22:46
links that validate your content is worth reading.  They don't need to be local. They don't need to be   from the most powerful domains on the internet.  They just need to be from reasonable sites. And  
22:56
you're going to need one per page at a minimum.  So for your 30 core 30 pages, that's 30 external  
23:01
links. Say that three times fast. Now, where do  you get these links? You can search them yourself   if you know how. You can reach out to relevant  blogs, to websites. You can use services that  
23:09
provide quality links. I actually run one of those  services. It's called the ice cream truck shop   that does this. There's a link in the description  if you want to check it out. We charge about $35  
23:16
per link. And now that might sound like a lot  until you remember that ranking in top three in   even a small city can easily generate six figures  in revenue per year. The Plano plumber I mentioned  
23:27
$50,000 in revenue in the next month alone from  the few thousand investment in doing content and  
23:33
links for his site. So these not AI swap links  tell Google that your content is legitimate and   trustworthy. But these links alone won't get you  to the top three. For that you need the second  
23:41
type of link, local authority links. These  are links from websites and organizations in   your local area that signal to Google that you  are a real trusted legitimate business in that  
23:51
community. And the absolute best local authority  link that you can get is your local chamber of  
23:56
commerce. Most cities charge between $200 and  $300 per year for a chamber membership. You  
24:02
join the chamber, they add your business to their  directory, and you get a link from their website   back to yours. Now, here's what makes chamber  links so powerful. Google recognizes chambers  
24:11
of commerce as local authority site. A link from  a chamber of commerce tells Google this business   is legitimate. They're active in the community  and they're trusted. It's one of the strongest  
24:20
local trust signals that you can get. And here's  a secret most SEOs don't know. You can actually   join multiple chambers. If there are three or four  chambers of commerce within 70 mi of your business  
24:30
location, join all of them. I've had clients where  we join 10 different chambers of commerce. Each   one costs a couple hundred a year. It's usually  based on the number of employees that you have,  
24:39
but each one is a massive vote of trust, of local  trust. The chambers themselves, they don't care if  
24:45
you're 30 m outside the primary city, as long  as you're paying the membership fee. Beyond   chambers, you want to look out for other local  organizations, youth sports leagues that need  
24:54
sponsorships, local charities, community events,  any local organization that has a website and will  
24:59
link to your local business if you sponsor them.  Now, clearly, most of these opportunities cost   money. You're sponsoring a little league team  for a few hundred dollars or you're donating to  
25:08
a charity gala event, but you're getting real  local links that Google values. And like to be  
25:14
honest here, these sponsorships and donations  are actually good for your business anyway.   You're building real community connections.  You're not just buying links. Of course,  
25:22
if we put our SEO blinders on, then yes, we're  also buying great links. Now, I used to have an   employee who spent almost all of her time just  looking for these organizations. Now, she mostly

27:09

27:15

27:26

28:14

28:19
than Gary, Indiana. So to decide what content  to produce next, we're going to think about a  
28:25

28:33
the top players are at 40%, your threshold is 15  to 20. That is your topical relevance threshold.  
28:39
If you're below that threshold, Google doesn't  trust you yet. Google doesn't believe that you   actually perform that service with a level of  expertise that your competitors have. You need  
28:48
more topical relevance, more content proving you  know what you're talking about. But if you're at   or above your topical relevance threshold,  that's a sign that Google trusts you. Google  
28:57
believes you're an authority on this service. So  now the strategy shifts. You don't need to prove   you're an expert. You need to expand how far away  from your address you can rank. So we're going to  
29:06
shift to building geographical relevance. This  decision point is critical because honestly most  
29:11
agencies don't do this or they get it backwards.  They start immediately building location pages.  
29:16
Plumber and Memorial Heights, plumber in River  Oaks before they've proven topical authority.   And those location pages do nothing because Google  just doesn't trust them yet. Or they keep building  
29:26

29:31
that they should be expanding geographically. The  rank map and the top three metric tell you exactly  
29:36
where you are and what to do next. If you're below  your threshold, you need more topical relevance.   And I'm going to show you exactly how to build  that next. If you're at or above your threshold,  
29:46
it's time for geographical relevance. I'll walk  through that after I talk about topical. So,   starting with topical relevance. What to do when  Google doesn't trust you're an expert yet. So,  
29:55
when Google doesn't believe you're an authority,  throwing more service pages at it won't help. You   need supporting content. Google doesn't trust you  perform this service at the level your competitors  
30:05

30:14

30:19
plumbing in America. Or they'll tell you to create  city pages, plumber in Houston, plumber in Katie,   plumber in Sugarland. Just changing the city name  and calling it content. These tactics don't work.

30:58

31:03
you're building here are not blog posts. They're  highly targeted supporting content pages built to   answer specific questions that the rank map shows  you're not ranking for. Every piece of content has  
31:12
a purpose. Every page is connected to your core 30  structure. Nothing is generic. Nothing is fluffy.  
31:18
Now, think about this. When someone is an expert,  they can easily answer detailed questions about   their field. They know the nuances. They know  the problems people actually have. This is what  
31:27
Google is looking for. So, you're going to find  FAQs, frequently asked questions related to the  
31:32
target keyword, and you're going to answer them  comprehensively. So, there are two main sources   for finding these questions. The first is Google's  people also ask section. Go to Google and search  
31:42
for your target keyword. Plumber, water heater  replacement. Leave the city name off and whatever   you're targeting. Scroll down and you'll usually  see a people also ask section with four or five  
31:51
questions. Click on any question and more will  appear. Keep clicking and you can easily find 20   to 30 relevant questions. Here's a quick example.  I type in plumber and then I can find right here  
31:59
people also ask. And if I click on this a few  times, I get more and more and more people also  
32:06
ask questions that keep showing up. Now, here's  what you need to know. Do not copy these questions  
32:11
word for word. I used to say to copy them word  for word. Every SEO I know used to say to copy  
32:16
them word for word. The problem is SEOs have  abused this people also ask section. They've   abused it so much that Google is getting wise to  it. So, if you just copy the exact question and  
32:25
structure content around them, Google's going to  know what you're doing. It's not going to build as   much authority. So, instead, we're going to reword  the question. Use a different word order. Make  
32:32
sure they mean the same thing, but phrase them  slightly differently. Google will understand. It's   built on the same transformer technology that chat  GPT uses. So, how much does it cost to replace a  
32:40
water heater becomes what's the typical price for  water heater replacement? It's the same question,   just different words. Okay. The second source is  Reddit. Rather than scrolling Reddit yourself,  
32:49
grab this prompt. Give the prompt your city  and your service and it's going to go and crawl   Reddit, find questions that real people in your  area are asking about your service on Reddit. Now,  
32:59
these are gold because they, like I said, they're  actual local questions from real people. These are   not generic people also ask questions. They're  specific about your service in your city.
33:15
Once you have these FAQs from these two different  sources, here's how you're going to use them.   You're going to add the question to the relevant  page on your site. If it's a general plumbing  
33:23
question, it's going to go on your homepage  or the main plumbing category page. If it's   specific to water heaters, it goes on your water  heater service page. If it's about drain lines,  
33:32
it goes on your drain line page. Then you're  going to answer the question briefly, a couple   dozen words, just enough to give a quick answer.  Then you're going to add an editorial link right  
33:42
in that content. Contextual natural something  like water heater replacement typically costs  
33:47
between $2,000 and $4,000 in Houston depending  on the type and installation complexity. For   a detailed breakdown of pricing factors, see our  complete guide to water heater replacement costs.  
33:56

34:37
